metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript Object Protection
Object Protection Methods

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Returns true if properties can be added to an object
// Prevents adding and deleting object properties
// Returns true if object is sealed
// Prevents any changes to an object
// Returns true if object is frozen

syntax_highlighting.text: // Returns true if properties can be added to an object
// Prevents adding and deleting object properties
// Returns true if object is sealed
// Prevents any changes to an object
// Returns true if object is frozen

content.code_html:
// Prevents re-assignment
 const car = {type:"Fiat", model:"500", color:"white"};

// Prevents adding object properties
 Object.preventExtensions(object)

// Returns true if properties can be added to an object
 Object.isExtensible(object)

// Prevents adding and deleting object properties
 Object.seal(object)

// Returns true if object is sealed
 Object.isSealed(object)

// Prevents any changes to an object
 Object.freeze(object)

// Returns true if object is frozen
 Object.isFrozen(object)

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Returns true if properties can be added to an object
// Prevents adding and deleting object properties
// Returns true if object is sealed
// Prevents any changes to an object
// Returns true if object is frozen

content.text: Using const
The most common way to protect an object from being changed is by using the const keyword.
content.html: The most common way to protect an object from being changed is by using the const keyword.

content.text: With const you can not re-assign the object, but you can still change the value of a property, delete a property or create a new property.
content.html: With const you can not re-assign the object, but you can still change the value of a property, delete a property or create a new property.

content.text: JavaScript Object.preventExtensions()
The Object.preventExtensions() method prevents adding properties to an object.
content.html: The Object.preventExtensions() method prevents adding properties to an object.

content.code_html:
// Create Object
 const person = {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe"};

// Prevent Extensions
 Object.preventExtensions(person);

// This will throw an error
 person.nationality = "English";

content.text: Since arrays are objects, arrays can be prevented from extensions too:
content.html: Since arrays are objects, arrays can be prevented from extensions too:

content.code_html:
// Create Array
 const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
Object.preventExtensions(fruits);

// This will throw an error:
 fruits.push("Kiwi");

content.text: JavaScript Object.isExtensible()
You can use Object.isExtensible() to check if an object is extensible.
content.html: You can use Object.isExtensible() to check if an object is extensible.

content.text: The Object.isExtensible() returns true if an object is extensible.
content.html: The Object.isExtensible() returns true if an object is extensible.

content.code_html:
// Create Object
 const person = {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe"};

// Prevent Extensions
 Object.preventExtensions(person);

// This will return false
 let answer = Object.isExtensible(person);

content.text: JavaScript Object.seal()
The Object.seal() method prevents additions or deletions of new properties.
content.html: The Object.seal() method prevents additions or deletions of new properties.

content.text: The Object.seal() method makes existing properties non-configurable.
content.html: The Object.seal() method makes existing properties non-configurable.

content.text: The Object.isSealed() method can be used to check if an object is sealed.
content.html: The Object.isSealed() method can be used to check if an object is sealed.

content.text: Note
The Object.seal() method will fail silently in non-strict mode and throw a TypeError in strict mode.
content.html: The Object.seal() method will fail silently in non-strict mode and throw a TypeError in strict mode.

content.code_html:
"use strict"
// Create Object
 const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  age: 50,
  eyeColor: "blue"
};

// Seal Object
 Object.seal(person)

// This will throw an error
 delete person.age;

content.text: Since arrays are objects, arrays can be sealed too:
content.html: Since arrays are objects, arrays can be sealed too:

content.code_html:
// Create Array
 const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
Object.seal(fruits);

// This will throw an error:
 fruits.push("Kiwi");

content.text: JavaScript Object.isSealed()
The Object.isSealed() method can be used to check if an object is sealed.
content.html: The Object.isSealed() method can be used to check if an object is sealed.

content.text: The Object.isSealed() returns true if an object is sealed.
content.html: The Object.isSealed() returns true if an object is sealed.

content.code_html:
// Create Object
 const person = {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe"};

// Seal Object
 Object.seal(person);

// This will return true
 let answer = Object.isSealed(person);

content.text: JavaScript Object.freeze()
The Object.freeze() method prevents any changes to an object.
content.html: The Object.freeze() method prevents any changes to an object.

content.text: Frozen objects are read-only.
content.html: Frozen objects are read-only.

content.text: No modification, addition or deletion of properties are allowed.
content.html: No modification, addition or deletion of properties are allowed.

content.text: Note
The Object.freeze() method will fail silently in non-strict mode and throw a TypeError in strict mode.
content.html: The Object.freeze() method will fail silently in non-strict mode and throw a TypeError in strict mode.

content.code_html:
"use strict"
// Create Object
 const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  age: 50,
  eyeColor: "blue"
};

// Freeze Object
 Object.freeze(person)

// This will throw an error
 person.age = 51;

content.text: Since arrays are objects, arrays can be frozen too:
content.html: Since arrays are objects, arrays can be frozen too:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
Object.freeze(fruits);

// This will trow an error:
 fruits.push("Kiwi");

content.text: JavaScript Object.isFrozen()
The Object.isFrozen() method can be used to check if an object is frozen.
content.html: The Object.isFrozen() method can be used to check if an object is frozen.

content.text: The Object.isFrozen() returns true if an object is frozen.
content.html: The Object.isFrozen() returns true if an object is frozen.

content.code_html:
// Create Object
 const person = {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe"};

// Freeze Object
 Object.freeze(person);

// This will return true
 let answer = Object.isFrozen(person);

content.html: Complete JavaScript Object Reference.
